frameDefinitions: An Agent acts in a certain Manner either generally or under some particular Circumstances.
Words in this frame have to do with a Cognizer believing that some Phenomenon will take place in the future.
Due to internal forces/properties, an Entity is inclined towards a particular Behavior, which may be to perform an action or to maintain a state.
This frame has to do with the repetition (and especially the frequency of repetition) of an event.
An Activity takes some Time_length to complete.

A Manner describes general or specific characteristics of an event in one of three ways:  First, it can refer to how a Comparison_event transpires, absent the influence of an entity (e.g. 'the way you talk').
frameExamples: He pledges to  <t>conduct</t> himself  with honesty and humility.
China will have to face a high <t>frequency</t> of sand storms in the years to come.
He completed the task in a fervent <t>manner</t>.
listRoleDefinitions: This role marks expressions that denote the person whose conduct is being evaluated.
This role marks expressions that characterize the way that the <fen>Agent</fen> behaves.
The <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Agent</fen> behaves in a certain way.
The location at which the <fen>Agent</fen> exhibits their behavior.

This is the person who believes some Phenomenon will take place in the future. It is normally expressed as an External Argument: <fex name='Cognizer'>Pat</fex> <t>expects</t> that the Yankees will win the World Series.

This is what the Cognizer believes will happen in the future. It can be expressed as a Finite Clause Complement, an NP Object, or a VP Complement with or without an NP Object (see General Grammatical Observations):
An entity that serves as the focus of a predicted <fen>Phenomenon</fen>.
The time when the <fen>Cognizer</fen> makes the prediction.
The location where the <fen>Cognizer</fen> foresees the <fen>Phenomenon</fen>.
TheFrame Element <fen>Entity</fen> identifies the person or thing that has a tendency towards some Behaviour.
The role <fen>Behavior</fen> marks expressions that indicate which state or action the <fen>Entity</fen> tends towards.
This role is used for any (bounded) <fen>Event</fen> whose frequency or iteration is described.
The extent to which the actually observed rate of occurrence of the <fen>Event</fen> or <fen>Salient_entity</fen> differs from the expected rate.
The <fen>Interval</fen> is a noun modified by the target word. The target word specifies the frequency of the <fen>Interval</fen> .
The <fen>Time_span</fen> is the length of time of the <fen>Interval</fen>. This role is incorporated by most of the lexical units in this frame.
The number of times per unit of real or scanning time that an <fen>Event</fen> or <fen>Salient_entity</fen> is encountered.
An entity which the implicit cognizer encounters with the specified frequency.
The frequency feature of the <fen>Event</fen> or <fen>Salient_entity</fen> that is under discussion. All the lexical units in this frame incorporate this frame element.
The Time when the Event has a particular frequency.
The event which requires some <fen>Time_length</fen> for completion.
The amount of time required for the <fen>Activity</fen>.
A modifier expressing  the deviation of the <fen>Time_length</fen> from the norm.
The individual who performs the <fen>Activity</fen>.
The <fen>Time</fen> at which the <fen>Activity</fen> takes place.

The <fen>Comparison_event</fen> is the principal event being characteriszed by the <fen>Manner</fen>. The <fen>Manner</fen> of this <fen>Comparison_event</fen> is often used in comparison with the <fen>Foreground_event</fen>.
The <fen>Salient_entity</fen> that is associated with or directly responsible for the <fen>Comparison_activity</fen>.
The description of the <fen>Comparison_event</fen> or <fen>Comparison_activity</fen>.
A description of the <fen>Manner</fen>.
The <fen>Salient_entity</fen> conducts or engages in the <fen>Comparison_activity</fen> that is being described.
listRoleExamples: <fex>Douglas Hurd</fex> carried himself well
They stood together and posed for the pass, Alleyne relaxed and smiling , a tall , angular man who carried himself <fex>with natural elegance</fex> .
She knew that she had behaved badly <fex>last night</fex>

Sometimes an offender may be placed at a Probation hostel because they have committed
a serious offence or have behaved badly <fex>at an independent hostel</fex>
Pat expects <fex>that the Yankees will win the World Series</fex>.
Predictions <fex>about stock prices</fex> are notoriously undependable.
She predicted the outcry <fex>several months ago</fex>.
<fex>Even at the far side of the house</fex> I could predict what was going on the kitchen.
<fex>Lubomir</fex> was not inclined to believe me
Martha has a tendency <fex>to overdo the housekeeping</fex>.
The country has been struck by frequent <fex>economic crises</fex>.
The Crested Lark (Galerida cristata) is  <fex>very</fex> frequent from the coastal plain to the mountains.
The meetings occurred at fortnightly <fex>intervals</fex>.
You have to renew the license every <fex>year</fex> .
The state government spends its fiscal year 2006 budget of $23.4 billion at a rate <fex>of $742 per second</fex>.
It costs about US$2.50 to travel 200km (124 mi), but <fex>buses</fex> are infrequent and only one or two buses a day service most routes.
These exposures were likely to be intermittent <fex>in frequency</fex> occurring only when workers were participating in activities at these specific areas.
Mona had a speedy <fex>recovery</fex>.
It'll only take <fex>20 seconds</fex>.
That took an hour  <fex>last week</fex>.

sourceCandidateSpans.text: the West Virginia Office of Miners' Health Safety and Training
the U.S. Mine Safety and Health Administration
